case_name: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax
court: High Court of Judicature, at Bombay

facts.text: Ciba India Ltd. appointed Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla as selling agent for the District of Ahmedabad for certain dyes and dye-stuffs by agreement dated October 29, 1928, agreeing to pay commission at 12 1/2% on sales

anchor.surface_text: By an agreement dated October 29, 1928, Ciba  India  Ltd. - hereinafter called the principles - appointed one Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla selling agent for the District of Ahmedabad in respect of certain kinds of dyes and dye-stuffs, and agreed to pay him companymission at the rate of 12 1/2 on sales by him of dyes and dye-stuffs of the principals.

facts.text: The commission under the 1928 agreement was to include all charges in connection with upkeep of offices and godown, turnover rebates and contingency expense, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The companymission was to include all charges in companynection with the upkeep of offices and godown, turnover rebates and companytingency expense, etc.

facts.text: Terms relating to commission modified by agreement dated August 20, 1935: out of 12 1/2% commission, 7 1/2% as selling commission and 5% as compensation in lieu of contingency expenses like commission to dyeing-masters, agents, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The terms relating to companymission were modified by agreement dated August 20, 1935, and out of the companymission agreed to be paid, 7 1/2 was to be treated as the selling companymission and 5 was to be treated as companypensation in lieu of the companytingency expenses which the selling agent had to meet, such as companymission to dyeing-masters, agents, etc

facts.text: Rights of the selling agent assigned with consent of principals to the respondent company with effect from October 27, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The rights of the selling agent were assigned with the companysent of the principals to the respondent companypany with effect from October 27, 1947.

facts.text: In assessing income of the company for assessment year 1949-50, Income-tax Officer included Rs. 58,025 in taxable income, being difference between Rs. 1,90,538 received as 5% commission and Rs. 1,32,512 spent by company for charges selling agent to meet

anchor.surface_text: In assessing the income of the companypany for the assessment year 1949-50, the Income-tax Officer included in the taxable income Rs. 58,025, being the difference between Rs. 1,90,538 received by the companypany as 5 companymission and Rs. 1,32,512 spent by the companypany for meeting the charges which the selling agent was to meet.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld contention of the company that 5% commission was wholly exempt by virtue of section 4(3)(vi) of Income-tax Act, 1922 in computation of company income

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Appellant Tribunal, however, upheld the companytention of the companypany that in the companyputation of the income of the companypany, the 5 companymission was wholly exempt by virtue of section 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Commissioner moved Tribunal to draw up statement of case and refer question to High Court of Judicature at Bombay on whether 5% of selling agency commission is exempt under section 4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner then moved the Tribunal to draw up a statement of the case and to refer the following question to the High Court of Judicature, at Bombay Whether, on the facts of the case, a portion, viz., 5 of the selling agency companymission of 12 1/2 received by the assessee-company from M s. Ciba Ltd. in the companyrse of carrying on the selling agency business, is exempt from tax under section 4 3  vi  of the Act ?

facts.text: Tribunal referred only question: whether assessee-company held office or employment of profit within meaning of section 4(3)(vi) of Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal only referred the following question Whether the assessee-company held an office or employment of profit within the meaning of section 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Application by Commissioner to High Court for Tribunal to submit statement on original question rejected; High Court answered referred question in affirmative citing Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. CIT 1948 16 ITR 260

anchor.surface_text: The application preferred by the Commissioner to the High Court for calling upon the Tribunal to submit a statement on the question originally submitted was rejected, and the High Court answered the question referred by the Tribunal in the affirmative, observing that it had been companyclusively determined by their earlier decision in Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1948 16 I.T.R. 260.

facts.text: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla v. CIT 1948 16 ITR 260 arose out of assessment of income of original selling agent under same agency agreement

anchor.surface_text: which arose out of a proceeding for assessment to tax of the income of the original selling agent under the same agency agreement.

facts.text: High Court was under misapprehension as question referred by Tribunal had not been decided in earlier Tejaji judgment

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in so observing the companyrt was under some mis-apprehension for the question referred by the Tribunal had number been decided in the earlier judgment.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order answering referred question affirmatively and dismissing notice of motion

anchor.surface_text: Against the order passed by the High Court recording an answer in the affirmative on the question referred by the Tribunal and against the order dismissing the numberice of motion, the Commissioner appealed to this companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order dismissing Commissioner's application, remanded case directing High Court to call upon Tribunal to state case on question in Commissioner's application, without opinion on referred question answer

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt set aside the order passed by the High Court dismissing the application of the Commissioner and without expressing any opinion on the companyrectness or otherwise of the answer recorded by the High Court on the question referred by the Tribunal, remanded the case to the High Court with a direction that the Tribunal be called upon to state a case on the question raised in the application of the Commissioner.

facts.text: Case heard by High Court of Gujarat after transfer due to reorganization of State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The case was then heard by the High Court of Gujarat to which it stood transferred because of the reorganization of the State of Bombay.

facts.text: High Court of Gujarat held that 5% commission received by company represented special allowance to meet expenditure such as commission to dyeing-masters, agents, etc., and exempt from tax

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat held that the 5 companymission received by the companypany represented a special allowance to meet expenditure such as companymission to dyeing-masters, agents, etc., and was on that account exempt from tax.

facts.text: High Court of Gujarat held that company held an office or employment of profit

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the companypany held an office or employment of profit.

facts.text: Commissioner appealed to Supreme Court against High Court answers on original and supplementary questions

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner has again appealed to this companyrt against the answer recorded by the High Court on the original and supplementary question.

facts.text: Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla case decided by Bombay High Court in 1948 16 ITR 260

anchor.surface_text: Tejaji Farasram Kharawallas case 1948 16 I.T.R. 260.

facts.text: In Sharma Co. case, Allahabad High Court: assessee-firm sole selling agent of cotton mill received over Rs.67,000 for retail cloth shop management expenses, spent Rs.12,641, held exempt under section 4(3)(vi) pre-1955

anchor.surface_text: In Sharma Companys case , the assessee-firm, which was the sole selling agent of a companyton mill, received a sum exceeding Rs. 67,000 from the owners of the mills for the purpose of meeting the expenses in companynection with the management of a retail cloth shop on behalf of the mill and actually spent only Rs. 12,641.

facts.text: Finance Act, 1955 recast section 4(3)(vi) Income-tax Act 1922 with effect from April 1, 1955, providing exemption for special allowance to extent expenses actually incurred

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that Parliament has by the Finance Act, 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955, recast clause  vi  of section 4 3  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, and has expressly provided that the special allowance granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit to the extent to which such expenses are actually incurred for that purpose, was exempt from tax.

facts.text: Selling agent under the agreement holds an employment of profit

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit.

facts.text: No argument to the contrary advanced before Supreme Court on whether selling agent holds employment of profit

anchor.surface_text: No argument to the companytrary was advanced before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, discharged High Court answer to supplementary question, recorded new answer that portion of 5% commission wholly and necessarily incurred in year of account in performance of duties as selling agent is exempt under section 4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under section 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the companypany as selling agent.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 1,90,538 received by the companypany as 5 companymission

facts.text: Company spent Rs. 1,32,512 for meeting charges which selling agent was to meet

section 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 3  vi  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, as it stood in the year of assessment read as follows Any income, profits or gains falling within the following classes shall number be included in the total income of the person receiving them Any special allowance, benefit or perquisite specifically granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit.

issues.text: Whether the purpose for which the allowance is granted is alone determinative of the claim to exemption under section 4(3)(vi) of the Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: To qualify for exemption, the allowance must, it is clear, be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit. But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone number determinative of the claim to exemption.

arguments.claim: Finance Act 1955 amendment clarifies exemption only to extent expenses actually incurred

anchor.surface_text: Parliament has by the Finance Act, 1955, with effect from April 1, 1955, recast clause vi of section 4 3 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, and has expressly provided that the special allowance granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit to the extent to which such expenses are actually incurred for that purpose, was exempt from tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Legislature made clear only actual expenses exempt; principle applies pre-amendment

arguments.claim: Portion of 5% commission wholly and necessarily incurred in year of account is exempt under section 4(3)(vi)

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency commission received by the assessee company is exempt under section 4 3 vi of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the company as selling agent.

holdings.text: The purpose for which the allowance is granted is not alone determinative of the claim to exemption under section 4(3)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: To qualify for exemption, the allowance must, it is clear, be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit. But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone number determinative of the claim to exemption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language requires allowance granted to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred; purpose insufficient without regard to actual incidence and necessity.

holdings.text: An allowance intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred does not constitute real income of the grantee but expenditure by employer; surplus acquires character of additional remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: An allowance, though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit, intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does number companystitute any real income of the grantee. It is in truth expenditure incurred by the employer through the agency of the grantee. The intention of the framers of the Act was to grant exemption in respect of amounts received by the assessee, number for his own benefit, but for the specific purpose of meeting the expenses wholly and necessarily incurred or to be incurred in the performance of his duties as an agent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowance for specific expenses is employer expenditure via agent; unexpended surplus changes to income taxable as remuneration even if non-refundable.

holdings.text: The decision in Tejaji Farasram Kharawalla's case (1948) 16 ITR 260 does not correctly interpret section 4(3)(vi) as object of grant alone determines exemption.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the decision of the Bombay High Court in Tejaji Farasram Kharawallas case 1948 16 I.T.R. 260. that the object with which the grant is made by the employer determines the claim to exemption under section 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observations fail to give effect to key words 'to meet expenses wholly and necessarily incurred'; exemption limited to such expenses.

holdings.text: For special allowance covering period longer than year of account, Income-tax Officer must determine amount attributable to year of account and tax difference after actual expenses therein.

anchor.surface_text: income-tax being an annual tax in a case where the allowance is an ad hoc allowance which is to companyer a period longer than or ending after the year of account, or is a periodical allowance, the Income-tax Officer may under the Act exempt expenditure incurred in the year of account and numbermore, ... If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period companyered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would in our judgment, be the duty of the Income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax annual; prorate multi-year allowance to year of account and exempt only actual necessary expenses therein to avoid frustration of intent.

holdings.text: The selling agent under the agreement holds an employment of profit within section 4(3)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that the selling agent under the agreement with the principals holds an employment for profit. No argument to the companytrary was advanced before us.

holdings.text: That portion of 5% of the selling agency commission received by the assessee company is exempt under section 4(3)(vi) of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the company as selling agent.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under section 4 3  vi  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, which is wholly and necessarily incurred in the year of account in the performance of the duties of the companypany as selling agent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies section 4(3)(vi) to facts: exemption only for portion meeting expenses wholly necessarily incurred in performance of duties in relevant year.

holdings.text: In the context in which the expression 'incurred' occurs, it undoubtedly means incurred or to be incurred.

anchor.surface_text: The clause grants exemption in respect of expenses incurred, but on that account an allowance granted to meet expenses to be incurred in future in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit is number outside the exemption claimed. In the companytext in which the expression incurred occurs, it undoubtedly means incurred or to be incurred.

anchor.surface_text: To qualify for exemption, the allowance must, it is clear, be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit. But the purpose for which the allowance is granted, in our judgment, is alone number determinative of the claim to exemption.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under section 4 3  vi of the
nce granted to meet expenses to be incurred in future in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of profit is number outside the exem

edges.explanation: h1 that purpose not alone determinative rebuts p3's view that purpose alone suffices without actual check [REPAIRED: rebuts->applies]

anchor.surface_text: ear, be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of prof

An allowance, though made to a person holding an office or employment of profit, intended for appropriation towards expenditure incurred or to be incurred in the discharge of the duties, does number companystitute any real income of the grantee. It is in truth expenditure incurred by the employer through the agency of the grantee. The intention of the framers of the Act was to grant exemption in respect of amounts received by the assessee, number for his own benefit, but for the specific purpose of meeting the expenses wholly and necessarily incurred or to be incurred in the performance of his duties as an agent.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under section 4 3  vi of the
ear, be granted to meet expenses incurred or to be incurred wholly and necessarily in the performance of the duties of an office or employment of prof

income-tax being an annual tax in a case where the allowance is an ad hoc allowance which is to companyer a period longer than or ending after the year of account, or is a periodical allowance, the Income-tax Officer may under the Act exempt expenditure incurred in the year of account and numbermore, ... If it appears from a review of the circumstances that a special allowance is made for a period longer than the year of account, or that the period companyered by the grant of a special allowance extends beyond the close of the account year, it would in our judgment, be the duty of the Income-tax Officer to determine the amount allowed in respect of the year of account in which the expenditure has been incurred, and the difference between the amount so determined and the amount actually expended would alone be brought to tax.

The appeal is therefore allowed and the answer recorded by the High Court to the supplementary question is discharged, and the following answer to the supplementary question is recorded That portion of 5 of the selling agency companymission received by the assessee companypany is exempt under section 4 3  vi of the
